feed.title: Movie Review: Friends With Kids
feed.subtitle: Bridesmaids with babies? Not quite, but writer/director/star Jennifer Westfeldt reunites much of the ensemble from summer's big comedy for this thought-provoking rom-com.

content.div:
Starring: Jennifer Westfeldt, Adam Scott, Jon Hamm, Kristen Wiig

Rating: Three out of five stars

"Which would you rather?" queries Julie, Friends With Kids' quadruple-threat writer-director-producer-star Jennifer Westfeldt, to her best friend Jason (Adam Scott, beloved of TV's Parks and Recreation). "Shriveled ovaries and a ring on your finger years from now, maybe if you're lucky, or a kid now and a life of freedom and leisure to find your soul mate?"

I'm paraphrasing, but that's the idea. They're pals so close that interrupting bedtime reading of Richard Dawkins is OK. In an uncannily similar movie, Billy Crystal's Harry once opined that men and women can't be friends "because the sex part always gets in the way," but in 20 years, that doesn't seem to have impeded Jason and Julie's intense but completely platonic friendship. She knows all about his sex life; he affectionately calls her "doll" and doesn't mind her chatty phone interruptions at 4:18 a.m., even when each of them have dates slumbering next to them in bed.

Of their tight-knit group of friends Ben and Missy (Jon Hamm and Kristen Wiig) and Leslie and Alex (Saturday Night Live alum Maya Rudolph and a sleepy-eyed Chris O'Dowd, the funny-sweet-awkward dreamboat cop from Bridesmaids), Jason and Julie are the last two hold-outs not yet paired up with anyone, let alone starting families. Not for lack of trying on Leslie's part, who's perpetually setting Julie up. "He's a criminal. But it's a white-collar crime. You can make that work," Leslie quips.

Going in, given the movie's hilarious trailer, stellar comedic cast and mastermind Westfeldt (of 2001's indie hit Kissing Jessica Stein), I was expecting Bridesmaids, With Babies. Instead, it was more Up All Night by way of Grey's Anatomy, but for grown-ups, with perfectly timed beats, plentiful porn jokes and, before the opening credits even begin, the word vagina uttered a few times.

The film may nominally be about children and how they can fray relationships and change friendships, but here's the rub: there's nothing to make you believe that either Jason or Julie actually want kids. It's just that Julie, now 38, is reaching her uterine sell-by day. And then, of course, there's the premise of the film. It wouldn't be much of a story if the two didn't get parental urges, but the very fact that these two contented characters suddenly felt the need came as a surprise. The sincerity of their longing for rugrats was more in the order of, "How about some Chinese take-out tonight?"

Nevertheless, there's that title to live up to. The friends' brilliant plan? To beat the system with none of that sex stuff to cloud it. "This is clean, simple," Jason boasts. Has fate ever been so tempted?

Their bargaining sessions, while laudably practical and often funny, feel rushed and untrue. The same goes for the resolution -- the ambiguity is never real, and with nothing at stake, the "will they or won't they?" angle (and if so, when and how?) doesn't much matter.

One night of red wine- and tequila-soaked awkwardness ("I'm sorry I don't have big t--s, I know that's your thing") seems to do the trick and the arrangement starts out promisingly enough. Conveniently, they live in the same rent-stabilized apartment building, their child care shifts separated only by an elevator ride.

Complications, of course, ensue when each starts dating again. The 15-year-old film The Object of My Affection explored similar terrain but with more courage, and was triumphantly bittersweet. Two-thirds of the way through Friends With Kids, the film that started out as a smart and snappy and just plain right-on alt-romantic-comedy devolves into a not-smart-enough and rather trite rom-com. (Even the gorgeously and poignantly profane rings hollow.)

This was an independent production, yet the third act feels like it was focus-grouped to death and massaged by a studio to play well with test audiences. It's kind of like how on Friends, the writers began exploring how Ross and Rachel might make co-parenting as singles work, but before it got too complicated, nuanced and interesting for a 22-minute episode, gave up and just paired them off in time for the series finale.

For all their charm, Jason and Julie are, fundamentally, Manhattan-centric stereotypes who bemoan a $70 cab ride across the bridge and have the sometimes-smug selfishness of the child-free.

"It's the baby card and Brooklyn," Julie laments after a frazzled, toddler-overrun Leslie and Alex. "We don't know those people." There's truth to that, and that's what makes the movie interesting. The joy of no-sex and co-sleeping toddlers mix with intelligent, wry one-liners (one date gets rejected because "she over-French-pronounces French words") and the true, cruel things people occasionally think about even their closest friends.

Alas, the ensemble is underutilized in favour of the (non-existent) romantic tension. Ben and Missy's disintegrating marriage -- parenting breeds contempt! -- and their respective meet-cutes had potential. So, too, do Ed Burns' sensitive hunky divorced contractor and Megan Fox who, in spite of her best intentions, manages to voice all the wrong, judgmental things about parenthood that people without kids say.

Friends With Kids may ultimately be pat, but in a few moments, Westfeldt pushes so many interesting buttons that you'll be discussing it for weeks. And really, which would you rather watch? Just another perfectly formulaic rom-com, or one that, even while flawed, still gives you plenty to think and argue about?
